instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PPVCORE_GPU: What is PPVCORE_GPU? This is the main power rail for the GPU. This is required for the GPU to turn on so you can get image on the display. .
definitions.PPVIN_S5_HS_OTHER5V_ISNS: What is PPVIN_S5_HS_OTHER5V_ISNS? PPVIN_S5_HS_OTHER5V_ISNS IS PPBUS_G3H voltage after it has passed through a current sense resistor that supplies the TPS51980 and its associated buck converter with voltage to create the PP5V_S4 power rail..
definitions.A1398: What is A1398? A1398 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2015, Mid 2012, Early 2013, Late 2013, Mid 2014 with EMC 2909, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00138, 820-00163, 820-00426, 820-3332, 820-3662, 820-3787..
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.3V3_S0: What is 3V3_S0? Abbreviation for PP3V3_S0, a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.S4_PWR_EN: What is S4_PWR_EN? S4_PWR_EN turns on the S4 power rails. Signals ending in _EN enable whatever came before _EN in the signal name when the voltage of the signal is high. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..

threads.title: 820-000163 sudden death
threads.message:
Hi,
I got a macbook from our supplier that was working fine, they said that they truned it off and the next day it didnt work anymore. There is no signs of water damage on the board, when I connect the charger the magsafe LED turns on green then amber and stays like that, there is no signs of shortage anywhere, all power lines that are "always present" according to the schematics are there, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> and other are there as well but then all goes to 0v after couple of seconds once magsafe LED turns amber (power lines "always present" are still present) . Anyone have any idea what could be wrong or what could I check next?
Thank you in advance.

threads.title: 820-000163 sudden death
threads.message:
Likely bad CPU, caused by (in)famous FDMF6808N chips.
Do you get VCORE in the first seconds at least?
Try to start in SMC bypass and see what happens.
You can try to replace FDMF6808 with (real) new FDMF6708, from Mouser.

threads.title: 820-000163 sudden death
threads.message:
This doesn't sound like random shutdowns but rather no power...
Voltage on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>? Post all voltages that you can need numbers. Also using OEM KNOWN GOOD 85 watt magsafe 2?

threads.title: 820-000163 sudden death
threads.message:
SMC bypass didnt help - it doesnt do anything, voltages around FDMF6808`s are looking good, the charger im using in the shop is 60w but I assume that the owner have an original charger on which it stopped working, that machine was in other repair shop where they said that there is no way to fix it. Volstages on some of the power lines that I have measured are as follow:

<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.44v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>        = 5.01v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>        = 5.03v
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> = 17.08v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>      = 3.33v
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_HS_COMP_ISNS</SIGNAL> = 12.63v
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_HS_OTHER5V_ISNS</SIGNAL> = 12.63v
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_HS_OTHER3V_ISNS</SIGNAL> = 12.63v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>   = 12.63v
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> = 1.79v
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> = 1.79v
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL>  = 0.85V

threads.title: 820-000163 sudden death
threads.message: There is your problem you MUST have an 85 watt for this board! All your voltages are present which is strange, but this sounds like wrong charger to me.

threads.title: 820-000163 sudden death
threads.message: ok, so I tried to run in on 85w charger and now all the power lines stays on, macbook is turning on but there is no image, no backlight, the magsafe LED goes on green and changes to amber like before, when trying to turn it on with SSD or  touchpad connected, it wownt turn on(got it only once to turn on with them connected). I dont know but it looks to me like north bridge have to be reflowed? that would make sense since it broke down after cool off.

threads.title: 820-000163 sudden death
threads.message: Do NOT reflow any CPU or PCH...do you get a light on a USB mouse? Any external video?

threads.title: 820-000163 sudden death
threads.message: USB mouse works fine but i dont get anything through HDMI

threads.title: 820-000163 sudden death
threads.message: Ok so this could be many things then. Have you at least tried a new 2015 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> display? Do you get 5 volts at the LCD for LCD power?

threads.title: 820-000163 sudden death
threads.message: No I didnt check new display as we dont have any other one in the shop and yes I get 5v for LCD, and since HDMI doesnt give any image I would assume that there is something wrong with RAM or north bridge?

threads.title: 820-000163 sudden death
threads.message: Disconnect the internal LCD and try again to see if any external. If you have 5 volts at the LCD, I would assume bad screen.

threads.title: 820-000163 sudden death
threads.message: ok, so it turns out that we have image on LCD and HDMI but need to whait a bit longer for it, I found out that when the machine is cold it runs with touchpad and (I made a mistake in previous post saying SSD) wifi card disconnected otherwise it doesnt start, when the machine is warmed up I can shut it down, connect both touchpad and wifi card and it runs fine. I tried to find out what needs to be warmed up in order to get it running with everything connected by using heat gun and it looks like PCH, unless there is something else around PCH that gets the heat and starts to work.

threads.title: 820-000163 sudden death
threads.message: Lol I can no longer help here sorry

threads.title: 820-000163 sudden death
threads.message: yeah.. thats what I get all the time on my desk.. it cant be anything simple but always some mistery fault.. :D I think its a faulty PCH, I dont think it could be anything else

threads.title: 820-000163 sudden death
threads.message:
Check <CHIP>U2080</CHIP> area.
How varies <SIGNAL>PLT_RST_BUF_L</SIGNAL> on cold and heat state, w/ and w/o above mentioned devices connected?
Compare with <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> level.

threads.title: 820-000163 sudden death
threads.message:
Could condition:
Devices connected       <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> and [LEFT][COLOR=#353535][FONT=inherit]<SIGNAL>PLT_RST_BUF_L</SIGNAL> [/FONT][/COLOR][/LEFT] are 0v
Devices disconnection  [LEFT][COLOR=#000000][FONT=Arial]<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> and [/FONT][/COLOR][/LEFT][LEFT][COLOR=#353535][FONT=inherit]<SIGNAL>PLT_RST_BUF_L</SIGNAL> [/FONT][/COLOR][/LEFT][LEFT][COLOR=#000000][FONT=Arial] are 3.33v

Hot condition:
In both conditions (devices connected and disconnected), both power lines are at 3.33v[/FONT][/COLOR][/LEFT]

threads.title: 820-000163 sudden death
threads.message:
Change <CHIP>U2080</CHIP>.
Seems that one device pull down its output; on cold state.
Check for corrosion on that area.
Strange that <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> goes down too.

threads.title: 820-000163 sudden death
threads.message: No, its not the <CHIP>U2080</CHIP>, connecting WLAN or touchpad in cold state brings <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> down to 0v because <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_BUF_L</SIGNAL> is not present, this line is not present because <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> is not present because its not being generated by PCH

threads.title: 820-000163 sudden death
threads.message:
So you don't even get a pulse on <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL> in such case?
Try to start then in SMC bypass mode...

threads.title: 820-000163 sudden death
threads.message: SMC bypass doesnt work in this condition, if the machine is cold and either touchpad or WLAN is connected then there is nothing you can do with it, its completely dead. There is something that its common to both touchpad and WLAN that PCH doesnt like or the PCH itself is faulty i think

threads.title: 820-000163 sudden death
threads.message:
Check for pulse at basic signals, triggering <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> in that case.
Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS/S4?

threads.title: 820-000163 sudden death
threads.message: Ok, so the <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> line reads 3.42v and it drops to 0.41v after pressing PWR button, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is present just like <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> but <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> is missing because <TRANSISTOR>Q8002</TRANSISTOR> is not getting <SIGNAL>S4_PWR_EN</SIGNAL>, and this is because <CHIP>U8170</CHIP> is not getting <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> which is generated by PCH and <SIGNAL>SMC_S4_WAKESRC_EN</SIGNAL> generated by SMC

threads.title: 820-000163 sudden death
threads.message:
Don't you get a pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> when trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>?
Also check if <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> pulses at same time.
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> should stay high all the time.

threads.title: 820-000163 sudden death
threads.message: There is no pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> at all, I do have a pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>, it seats at 3.44v and it goes down to 0.14v after PWR button trigger, <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> reads 3.04v

threads.title: 820-000163 sudden death
threads.message:
Then is something related with PCH, as SMC reacts correctly.
If you connect only one of mentioned devices, board starts correctly?

threads.title: 820-000163 sudden death
threads.message: No, in cold state if WLAN or touchpad or both at once are connected it doesnt work, only if the machine is wormed up then it does, it also works in cold state, only when both devices are disconnected

threads.title: 820-000163 sudden death
threads.message:
Connect WLAN and remove L3505.
Test if starts on cold state.

Similar test for trackpad, removing L4803.
You can try changing <TRANSISTOR>Q8000</TRANSISTOR> directly.
At least check <TRANSISTOR>Q8000</TRANSISTOR>/02 voltages and their traces and surrounding components.

threads.title: 820-000163 sudden death
threads.message: tried connecting trackpad and WLAN withut inductors and it works fine also checked voltages around these FETs mentioned above and everything looks fine but with WLAN or trackpad (with inductors) <TRANSISTOR>Q8002</TRANSISTOR> is not getting <SIGNAL>S4_PER_EN</SIGNAL>, therefore no <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>
